transcripts.title: Most Men Are Using Color Wrongâ€”Hereâ€™s How to Fix It

transcript.text: Most men are using color completely
wrong. Not because they don't care about
design, but because no one ever showed
them how color actually works. So, today
I'm going to change that. Take a look at
this. This is what a lot of men have
been advised to do. Safe, neutral
modern. But let's be honest, this is
flat. It's forgettable. And it gives off
the same disconnected energy as hospital
artwork. Today, you're going to learn
how to paint a different picture. And
once you have that talent, you'll never
use color the same way again. If you're
a returning subscriber, hit the thumbs
up. If you're new here, hopefully by the
end of this video, you'll be a
subscriber. Remember that if you would
like our help in designing your room
you can have that help by clicking the
link in the description below. Color
isn't just paint. It's communication.
It's tone. It's volume. It's cadence. It
can be the difference between a room
that feels lost and one that feels
navigated. Before you choose a color
ask yourself, "What message do I want to
send? Is it bold? Is it calming? Is it
immersive?" Too often, men pick items
individually, like gadgets judged in
isolation. This bed frame looks solid
and masculine. Real wood carved. Done.
This reading chair's got character.
Comfortable pattern. Let's go. Oh, this
blue paint's cool. Grab a can. But no
one's asking how does the carved bed
frame interact with the patterned chair
surrounded by that particular shade of
blue. By the time it's all in the room
something feels off. The pieces don't
complement each other. They cannibalize.
And that's when the panic hits. Well, I
guess I'll just paint everything gray.
So, the space ends up cold and stripped
and soulless. If your room feels
detached, like it's missing something
it might not be your style. It might be
your color strategy. So, let's fix that.
Starting with the four words that you
should know. Hue, tint, shade, and tone.
These are the building blocks of every
great palette. Understand these and
you'll know exactly how to create a
space that feels masculine, directed
and well assembled. Hue is the pure form
of a color. Red, blue, green. Hues are
bold. They're loud. They're unfiltered.
They command attention, but in large
amounts, they can feel aggressive or
even childish. In masculine rooms, hues
work best as accents, not the main act.
Tint is what happens when you add white
to a hue. It softens the hue. It makes
it lighter, airier. Tints are useful for
balance. They lighten heavy pallets
without making the room feel weak.
Examples might be sage from its parent
hue green. putty from orange, pale olive
from yellow green. Use these to add
contrast in a calm, controlled way.
Shade is when you add black to a hue. It
deepens the color. It adds drama and
weight. Shades are your allies in
masculine design. Use them in wall
color cabinetry upholstery anywhere
you want impact and presence. Examples
might be burgundy from red, navy from
blue, or forest green, of course from
green. Tone is the most overlooked, but
possibly the most powerful. It's created
by adding gray to a hue, muting the
color without making it too light or too
dark. Tones are subtle, sophisticated
layered. They bring calm complexity to a
room, like toffee notes to a red wine.
Examples might be charcoal or stone
olive or muted cognac. Before we go
further, colors can feel overwhelming.
To help, we put together a free guide
with 10 masculine pallets that always
work. These are real combinations from
client projects that we've done, ready
to use. You can download it using the
link in the description below. Now that
you know the difference in terminology
let's talk strategy. Start with the
walls as your backdrop. Use shades or
tones to anchor that space. You want
depth and drama? Try navy, black, green
or iron gray. Do you want complexity
without darkness? Try taupe, muted
olive, or deep stone. Be cautious of
pure hues here, though. They can be
loud. They can be overpowering. Use
tints only in smaller rooms or when
paired with strong structured elements.
Large furniture pieces should complement
the walls without disappearing. If you
have dark walls, bring in rich leather
or warm toned woods. If you have toned
walls, we'll go for aged browns, black
or espresso finishes to ground that
space. Textiles are where contrast comes
in. Use tints, washed out versions of
your core palette to soften and break up
that visual heaviness. Pale sage
curtains, cream colored throws, light
olive pillows, they don't weaken the
space, they relieve it. Accents and
artwork are your chance to reintroduce
those hues but sparingly. A bold
painting, a vintage book spine, a brass
detail, or double down on tones and
materials like weathered metal, aged
leather, or smoky glass. The goal, a
room that feels evolved, not elementary.
Shade on the walls, tone in the
furniture, tint in the textiles, hue in
the accents. That's your color
composition. Let's talk about what ruins
those items. Well, mistake number one is
going all gray. It's common. It's safe
but it's flat. Gray everywhere means no
warmth, no focal point, no contrast. If
you like gray, fine, but give it
something to respond to. Wood, brass
ivory, something to form well-rounded
character. Mistake number two is going
to be having no contrast. If everything
is light, nothing pops. If everything is
dark, it's heavy. You need visual
tension. Pair dark walls with lighter
accents or light walls with rich, dark
furniture. Mistake number three is pure
hues but poorly used. Red, blue, yellow.
Great in small doses, but used in
multiple wall colors or main furniture
pieces, they often feel juvenile.
Instead, consider this. Do you love red?
Try ox blood leather. Do you love blue?
Go deep sea. It's about maturation, not
intensity. Mistake number four is going
to be ignoring the undertones. This one
can sneak up on you. Even if you think
your palette is cohesive, clashing
undertones can ruin everything. Always
ask questions like, "Is this warm or
cool gray? Is this beige leaning pink or
yellow?" If undertones are fighting each
other, it's very difficult to cover up
the scars. Avoiding these mistakes isn't
harder. It's just smarter. Once you
understand hue, tint, shade, and tone
you stop guessing and you start
building. And that's what turns an okay
room into a powerful room. If you like
the video, hit the thumbs up. If you
feel like sticking around a while, feel
free to subscribe. See you on the next
one.
[Music]
[Music]

transcripts.title: Why This Room Feels So Damn Powerful

transcript.text: There's a reason this room hits you the
moment you step inside. It feels
powerful. But most men can't pinpoint
why. It's not just the furniture, not
just the paint. It's something deeper
something you feel before you even
realize it. And that feeling, that's
what we're chasing when we style a
space. Not just a finished look, but
clarity, accomplishment, a sense that
it's right. At first, this room didn't
have that. The vision was strong, but
the path was clouded. We've all been
there before. placing decor, adjusting
furniture, pulling in personal items.
But instead of locking into place, it
all feels off. And then comes the doubt
is this even working? Why doesn't it
feel how I pictured it? Today, I'll show
you how we cleared that fog and built a
room that speaks with confidence. A
space that doesn't just look complete
it feels undeniable. If you're a
returning subscriber, hit the thumbs up.
If you're new here, hopefully by the end
of this video, you'll be a subscriber.
Remember that if you would like our help
in designing your room, you can have
that help by clicking the link in the
description below. Jared and Kelly first
reached out for help refining their main
floor, an open concept space connecting
the family room, dining area, and
kitchen. They were drawn to that dark
moody, masculine aesthetic, but
struggled to balance that with the
lighter elements already present in
their home. Each attempt to fix it on
their own only added more confusion.
When they called us, it wasn't just for
a redesign. It was for relief. What they
did know was the kind of materials that
they were drawn to. Rich leather
stained wood, touches of metal. That
gave us a foundation. And when they
described their lifestyle, hunting
fishing hiking barbecues country
living, it became clear these were
outdoor people who needed a space that
brought the outside in. This wasn't just
about style. It was about identity.
Let's see what we came up with. This
design is a contemporary interpretation
of modern rustic layered with
mid-century restraint and subtle
industrial strength. What gives it its
edge isn't just the aesthetic, it's the
execution. Masculine refinement meets
design clarity in a space that feels
both grounded and evolved. It's a
balancing act. Clean lines meet raw
texture. Sleek form meets organic
warmth. And the result is a room that
feels rooted in tradition, but entirely
at home in the present. The first thing
you notice about this area is the
warmth. It's not loud. It doesn't shout
but it pulls you in. There's a magnetic
quality to the way that this space is
styled. Soft, immersive, planted. We
designed this open concept first floor
using neutrals in a way that makes them
feel bold, alive, expressive, but not
overwhelming. This is the kind of pallet
that speaks to many. It's striking but
approachable. If you're designing a
shared space, whether it be with a
partner or roommates or family, this is
the kind of approach that makes everyone
feel at home. There's nothing polarizing
or off-putting, but there's still
character, still identity. Interior
design is deeply personal. It reflects
our stories, our habits, our keepsakes.
And because of that, it's rare to find
two people who connect to the exact same
room in the exact same way. So, how do
you create a space with emotion and
meaning without alienating the people
who share it? That's the challenge. And
in this space, the solution was tone.
Tone is what makes this room feel so
layered, even though the color palette
is tight. Think of tone like a volume
knob on a single color. Dial it up, it
gets lighter. Dial it down, it gets
darker. But the core hue stays the same.
We're not using a rainbow of colors
here. We're working within a narrow
band, stretching it gently, molding it
creating contrast through shade and
depth rather than variety. It's a quiet
mastery, one that makes the room feel
rich without being complicated. Just as
well, this space doesn't rely on a
massive catalog of materials. It's not
filled with 15 different finishes or a
bothering mix of styles. Instead, it's a
refined composition built with a handful
of carefully chosen elements used
strategically. A similar approach to how
people once cooked during hard times.
Think about the Great Depression or the
World War. Families had limited
ingredients. Food was rationed, but
somehow meals still had flavor, still
satiating. Meat was scarce, so dishes
like shephardd's pie and potato soup
came to life. Flour was rationed, which
gave rise to cornbread and biscuits.
Sugar was rare, but people still found a
way to create morale boosting treats
like banana bread and rice pudding.
Those meals weren't just survival. They
were resourceful, creative, and deeply
satisfying. Design can be the same way.
When you limit your pallet, but push it
further, magic happens. We treated the
original space like a blank canvas. The
charcoal we introduced, that was our
pencil, used to draw depth, to add
definition, to guide the eye. Just like
a sketch of a face needs shadow to bring
out cheekbones and jaw lines, this room
needed that contrast to create shape and
movement. The result isn't flashy. It's
composed. A portrait of subtle
complexity, drawn not with color, but
with tone. Picking the right colors for
your space can feel confusing, but we've
made it simple. We created a free guide
with 10 masculine color palettes that
always look great, so you don't have to
worry about making the wrong choice.
These color combinations help any room
feel stylish and sophisticated and
welldesigned. Just click the link in the
description below, download your free
guide, and start upgrading your space.
At first glance, the ceiling features
look like forged black steel, an
industrial echo across the space. But
it's a crafted illusion. These beams are
actually popppler wood, handshaped, then
painted to mimic steel. It's a smart nod
to the industrial heritage without the
weight or coldness of actual metal. The
beams run boldly across the open floor
plan, anchoring the living, dining, and
kitchen zones with strong horizontal
continuity. They're not just a design
feature, they're a unifying force.
Within the family room, the leather sofa
has a patina that feels lived in, like
it belongs in a cabin or a private club.
But its boxy modern frame reigns it back
in. Classic material meets modern
silhouette. Flanking it, a pair of wood
framed lounge chairs bring a lighter
hand. Having roots in mid-century
design, they're sculptural without being
bulky. Their presence softens the space
while reinforcing symmetry. Underfoot, a
textured neutral rug brings in air and
softness, balancing the bold blacks
deep browns, and heavy woods. At the
center, we have a walnut coffee table
with raw metal legs in a stance of
purpose. Strong, understated, earthy.
Together, these elements form a tactile
comfortable composition, refined, but
rugged. The dining area is a meeting of
industrial and Scandinavian. Think 1920s
factory bones softened by contemporary
warmth. It's minimalism with soul.
Framing the space is a vertical wood
paneling, an architectural technique
that defines the dining zone without
enclosing it. It gives the impression of

transcript.text: You've bought the furniture, but the
room still feels cheap or unfinished
and you can't quite figure out why. If
you went the budget friendly route, you
already knew it wasn't heirloom quality
but it looked good, clean lines, decent
comfort. So, why does the room still
read as lacking? And if you spent
$20,000 on high-end pieces, why does it
still feel incomplete? You walk in
expecting pride, and instead you
experience doubt. The investment doesn't
shine. The space doesn't speak. And that
nagging question creeps in. Was any of
this worth it? Here's the truth. Most
people understand the basics of home
design. Paint the walls, buy the

creates a finished space. What's missing
is the final 20%. The styling, the
rhythm, the tension between bold and
soft, light and shadow. the invisible
layer that makes everything click.
That's what gives a room presence.

in this video, I'm going to show you
exactly how to add that back in. If
you're a returning subscriber, hit the
thumbs up. If you're new here, hopefully
by the end of this video, you'll be a
subscriber. Remember, if you would like
our help in designing your room, you can

the description below. Here are five

and how to fix that instantly. Layered
lighting is one of the most overlooked
upgrades in masculine interiors. And
yet, it's often the detail that signals
execution. It's not just about
brightness. It's about depth, shadows
mood, precision. Overhead lighting
alone, it flattens a room, makes it feel
cold and unfinished. But when you layer
light intentionally, everything shifts.
You can change the entire portrayal of a
space from crisp and functional by day
to warm and atmospheric by night.
Professionally designed rooms always use
multiple light sources. It's like
wearing a tailored suit instead of one
off the rack. You can feel the
difference, even if you can't always
explain why. This is how you can add
layered lighting quickly. Start with
table lamps. Place one on a console
desk, or side table. Choose rich
finishes, black wood, stone, leather, or
aged brass. Look for warm bulbs, 2700
Kelvin or less, with fabric, or
parchment shades to soften the glow. Add
wall sconces or picture lights. Battery
powered sconces are easy to install. No
wiring needed there. Use them to
highlight artwork, flank a mirror, or
elevate bookshelves. Use floor lamps in
corners. A tall lamp near an armchair or
a sofa will fill that visual dead space.
Go for minimal black steel, tripod
brass, or industrial silhouettes.
Install LED strip lighting behind
shelves, under consoles, or along
headboards. This soft architectural glow
will create intrigue with very little
effort. Candle light or natural flames
nature does it best. And if you can
safely showcase an open flame in your
room, pursue that. Understand that one
piece of art can elevate a room by
itself. Large scale art and strong
frames can instantly anchor a masculine
room. They communicate confidence
taste, and permanence. One large frame
piece can say much more than six tiny
pieces scattered across a wall. It feels
deliberate, like it was always meant to
be there. To include this quickly, pick
one dominant wall above the sofa, the
bed, or the fireplace. Center it at a
size roughly 23 the width of the
furniture piece below. Next, choose your
art. Buy preframed or download
highresolution copies of meaningful
works. Whether it's abstract
landscapes portraits surrealism
choose pieces with gravity. Print at
large scale. Print at 24x 36 or bigger.
Go matte paper or gi clay for a refined
finish. Finally, frame it like it
belongs in a library. Choose a wide
black, gold, or wood frame. Avoid those
skinny mass- prodduced ones. They
undercut the whole effect. Rug size, the
silent killer of good design. Too many
men pick a rug that's too small, and the
whole room suffers for it. A rug isn't
just decoration. It's the foundation. It
pulls your furniture together. It adds
warmth and it makes the room read as
intentional. Without it, the space
floats and not in a good way. Here is
how to fix your rug. Stand back and
re-evaluate. Is your rug actually
anchoring the furniture or just floating
under the coffee table? If the front
seating legs aren't on it, it's likely
too small. Upgrade one size up. Don't
just stop at 5 by8. In most cases, 8x10
or 9 by12 is what you really need. Add a
thick rug pad. It improves comfort
underfoot, creates visual weight, and
keeps the rug from sliding. If you're
unsure about which color to use, go
neutral in tone, strong in texture. J
Cecil, wool, or Persian style patterns
earth tones, charcoal, olive, or worn
red. They work beautifully in masculine
spaces. Imagine this setup. You have a
leather Chesterfield sofa, two
armchairs, and a coffee table. With a 5
by8 rug, it's a floating island. It
looks thrown together. Replace it with a
9x12. Now the room appears anchored
elegant, a proper formation. Picking the
right colors for your space can feel
confusing, but we've made it simple. We
created a free guide with 10 masculine
color palettes that always look great
so you don't have to worry about making
the wrong choice. These color
combinations help any room feel stylish
sophisticated, and well-designed. Just
click the link in the description below
download your free guide, and start
upgrading your space. Use decor that
feels collected, not cluttered. Accent
decor with intent isn't about filling
the shelves. It's about placing
meaningful objects with interest and
magnetism, not clutter, not filler.
Think in layers, think in textures, and
most of all, think in story. So, what
might classify as intentional accent
decor? Books, hard covers with texture
classic titles, topics like
architecture, military history
philosophy, fine spirits, objects
bronze sculptures, antique tools, bus
globes, cigar boxes, hourglasses, and
then tactile materials, marble, leather
bronze, wood, stone, anything that feels
substantial. Why it works? It adds
personality, says someone lives here.
It's not just a showroom. It creates
texture, visual and tactile contrast
will add that richness. It softens bold
design. Strong lines need soft touches
to feel livable. And then it signals
taste. A man who pays attention to the
little things. To begin styling with
intent, build one vignette at a time.
Try one low item like a book, one tall
item like a sculpture or a candle, and
then one raw material, brushed metal
wood, a plant. This assembly is
generally attractive. Use the tray rule.
Group items together on a tray to make
it feel styled and not scattered. Shop
with a story in mind. Ask yourself
would this belong in the kind of space
that I'm building? Stack books
horizontally, two to three hard covers
a decorative object. It's cultivated.
Mixed metals and finishes, brass with
fabric, leather beside wood. Contrasting
pairs brings charm. Window treatments
aren't just for privacy. In masculine
interiors, they're architectural. They
frame the room, soften the light, and
bring intentionality to the walls. Skip
them and the room runs the risk of
appearing halfway done. Here's how to
get these done right. Measure for
fulllength panels. Let curtains fall all
the way to the floor. No floaters. Hang
the rod four to six inches above the
window and extend that 8 to 12 inches
wider than the window. Use strong
masculine fabrics, heavy linen, wool
tweed, velvet. Explore deep greens
charcoals, navy. If you'd like, you can
layer for depth with multiple
treatments. Pair blinds with drapes
woven wood with linen, Roman shades with
velvet, and then upgrade the hardware.
Swap those cheap plastic rods and
brackets for oil rubbed bronze, matte
black, or solid wood. Incorporate these
five tips and you will find your room
springing to life like a plant that has
just been watered. If you like the
video, hit the thumbs up. If you feel
like sticking around a while, feel free
to subscribe. See you on the next one.

transcript.text: There are times when someone reaches out
to us with more than curiosity. They
come with conviction, not dipping their
toes, not testing the waters, but fully
committed to a vision. A vision that
isn't chasing trends. It's shaping
legacy. And when that happens, it's
electric. There's something powerful
about reaching into a world of story, of
history, and depth, and choosing to let
it speak through your space, to live in
it, to be surrounded by it. That's more
than design. That's intention. That's a
room that speaks for you. I truly
believe this. Change your surroundings
and you'll start to feel the shift
within yourself. If you're a returning
subscriber, hit the thumbs up. If you're
new here, hopefully by the end of this
video, you'll be a subscriber. Remember
that if you would like our help in
designing your room, you can have that
help by clicking the link in the
description below. Ricardo came to us
with a clear mission. redesigned the
entry area and the living room of his
new home completely. Not a refresh, a
transformation. The paint that he
started with was that all too familiar
lifeless gray that we've seen in too
many spaces. The floors, well, those are
likely untouched since the home was
built, but oddly enough, that worked in
our favor, and you'll see why soon. What
Ricardo emphasized most was this. He
wanted both spaces to be inspired by the
Peiquey Blinders. He's watched the
series more times than he can count
often letting it play in the background.
I can't blame him. I've done the same.
It's a fantastic show. And if you
haven't seen Mob Land yet, go ahead and
add that to your list. Now, for those
unfamiliar, Peiquey Blinders takes place
in Birmingham, England, beginning in
1919, just after World War I. It follows
the Shelby family as they claw their way

transcripts.title: The 5 Rug Styles Every Man Needs to Know

transcript.text: Most men overlook the one element that
silently defines the entire room. And
it's the difference between a room that
just looks nice and one that feels
powerful. Before we talk color, layout
or lighting, we need to talk about what
most guys are overlooking. It's the rug.
It's not just decor, it's a foundation.
The right rug adds structure to chaos.
It balances the bold, charges the dull
and subtly reshapes the room around it.
And that's where design becomes art. A
masculine space isn't just furniture
thrown in a room. It's a composition.
Patterns, textures, shadows, all forming
one singular image. And the rug, it's
either amplifying that vision or it's
quietly weakening it. Let me show you
five of the best rugs for masculine
interiors because once you understand
what they do, you'll never design the
same way again. The first rug is the
chunky jute or cyle rug. This is for
rooms that feel natural, grounded, and
relaxed. It adds raw texture, warmth
and visual weight. It doesn't compete
with other elements. It reinforces them.
A rug like this works especially well in
rooms with leather, wood, or matte black
accents. While Joot and Cyle are often
grouped together, they're not the same.
Joot rugs are softer underfoot with a
loose weave that gives them a more
casual, relaxed appearance, but that
same softness makes them less durable in
hightra areas. Usually, you'll find joot
to be naturally golden tan with warm
undertones. Joot works well in spaces
where comfort and casual texture are
often desired, like living rooms and
bedrooms. Something to consider is that
they absorb moisture easily and are not
ideal for hight traffic or damp areas.
Cyle rugs by contrast have a texture
that is more coarse and firm resulting
in a firmer underfoot feeling that also
stands up better to wear. Naturally cy
colors are pale beige to strawlike
making them a cooler tone than jute. You
can consider these for entryways
offices, dining rooms, anywhere you need
more durability. There is a price to pay
for that increased utility of cycle rugs
though. That is that they are not as
soft as Joot. They can feel scratchy if
you're walking across them barefoot. So
ultimately when do you use one versus
the other? Choose Joot when you want the
space to feel warm, approachable, and
tactile like a relaxed masculine retreat
or a lounge. Choose cycle when you need
a sharper, more tailored texture that
holds up to wear, especially in
transitional spaces or hightra zones. A
bonus tip for all of the rugs that we
talk about today is to never go so small
that the rug floats in the middle of the
floor. It weakens the whole room. Aim
for the front two legs of major
furniture to sit on top of the rug. Rug
number two is going to be the Persian or
oriental rug. This is for a room that
feels collected, intellectual, or
storied. It adds rich color, intricate
pattern, and a sense of history. It
helps the space feel layered and lived
in. These rugs are especially powerful
in rooms with deeper paint colors
bookcases, or vintage elements. The
terms Persian and oriental rugs are
often used interchangeably, but they
have distinct meanings, especially if
you're focused on authenticity, visual
character, and the message that a room
sends. Persian rugs originate
specifically from Iran, which is
formerly Persia. Their designs are known
for central medallions, floral or
curvealinear motifs, and detailed
borders. Generally, you'll find deep
reds, navy, ivory, emerald, and gold
color palettes. These rugs often feel
regal and academic. They're rich
formal, and refined. Most often, Persian
rugs are crafted through hand knotting
prized for their artistic heritage and
symbolism. The best rooms to use these
rugs are ones that lean traditional
classic, or scholarly, like home
offices, libraries, or moody lounges.
Oriental is a broader term when it comes
to the origin of a rug. This includes
rugs from Turkey, India, Afghanistan
China, Nepal, Pakistan, and Iran. The
designs can vary widely. Geometric
tribal patterns, repeating motifs, or
floral designs. The color palettes can
go either way in terms of tone. They can
be muted or they can be bold. They're
going to feel more diverse. They're
citizens of the world. You'll find them
to be global, rustic, or heritage driven
depending on the pattern. Some are hand
knotted, some are machine-made. If
you're designing a space that has a mix
of global influences, layered textures
and vintage character, like a study, a
loft, or a modern rustic room, an
oriental rug could be a good addition.
So, when should you use a Persian rug
versus an oriental rug? Choose a Persian
rug if you want a space to feel
elevated, collected, or intellectually
grounded. Something more formal with a
masculine impression, especially with
deep, classic color schemes. Choose an
oriental rug if you want a space to feel
worldly, storied, or texturally layered.
This is going to be the more flexible
route with pattern, culture, and tone.
If you want help choosing the right rug
for your space, and getting every other
element right around it, we built the
masculine style guide for you. It covers
10 signature interior styles, exact
paint names, layout guidance, and
material pairings that always work. You
can find it in the description below.
It'll save you time, avoid mistakes, and
give you a clear, confident design plan.
Next, we have the abstract or geometric
wool rug. These will fit comfortably in
rooms that feel modern, tailored, and
clean. They give structure, movement
and masculine rhythm, meaning the visual
cadence created by strong, intentional
shapes and repetition. There's visual
interest without chaos. These rugs are
great in spaces with neutral walls
mid-toned woods, or sculptural lighting.
Choose low pile wool, which is a short
tightly woven fiber rug for a sleeker
look and easier maintenance. You might
be thinking, "Okay, I get it. The
abstract or the geometric look, but why
wool?" Well, texture signals
sophistication. Wool adds a soft
natural texture that gives the rug
visual richness and tactile quality. In
masculine spaces, this subtle texture
helps balance the harder elements like
leather, metal, or stone, making the
room feel more complete rather than
cold. Remember that material equals
message. Abstract or geometric rugs made
of synthetic fibers can sometimes feel
flat or mass-produced. But when that
same design is crafted in wool, it
signals deliberateness, quality, or
timelessness. Three values which can be
considered core to the masculine design
aesthetic. So in short, you're looking
for the kind of intentional qualitybuilt
rug that supports the tone of a
masculine space. Wool is often the best
indicator of that. Geometric wool rugs
are repeating. They're orderly patterned
pieces lines shapes grids diamonds
etc. They feel structured, balanced, and
controlled. They're best for emphasizing
order or symmetry, mid-century, modern
or tailored spaces, or they're great
with grounding, bold furniture with a
calm visual base. A geometric rug
reinforces clean lines and structure.
Perfect if the rest of the home has
curves, texture, or layered elements. It
adds rhythm without havoc. Now, abstract
wool rugs are irregular, flowing, or
they're painterly in nature. No real
consistent repetition. They're more
expressive, dynamic, and artistic. These
are best for rooms that already feel
very structured or need movement or
softness spaces with moody or modern
masculine styles like lofts, lounges, or
art inspired offices. They also work
when you want the rug to be a subtle
conversation piece or visual lift.
Abstract rugs introduce emotion and
unpredictability. They soften the edges
and create contrast in spaces that might
otherwise feel too rigid or minimal. The
bottom line, use geometric when you want
order and basing. Use abstract when you
want movement and mood. The fourth rug
is the solid oversized neutral. This is
a wonderful addition to rooms that feel
calm, minimalist, or architectural. They
create visual, breathtaking rooms
without drawing attention. They'll help
larger rooms feel organized and
proportionate. You'll find that they
pair beautifully with stone, concrete
or soft white walls. Ideally, you're
looking for colors like charcoal or
taupe, oatmeal, maybe. Skip anything
that might be too bright or icy.
Oversized neutral rugs are almost always
better when they are plain or subtly
patterned and textured rather than flat.
But why? Plain or subtly patterned rugs
support minimalist and architectural
spaces by not drawing attention away
from the structure of the room. See
busy patterns create visual noise, which
works against the serenity and the
clarity that calm spaces are designed to
evoke. Textured rugs like looped wool
NY blends, or lightly raised designs, as
we've mentioned before, add warmth and
tactile interest without disrupting that
clean look. Texture brings depth to a
space that might otherwise feel cold or
sterile, especially when color in the
room is intentionally muted. What's the
reason they work so well in calm and
architectural rooms, though? Well, these
rooms rely on form, light, and restraint
to make their statement. An oversized
neutral rug anchors that space without
being decorative, letting architectural
elements and statement furniture shine
in the room. It also creates a feeling
of scale and cohesion, gently unifying
the layout without interrupting it. What
do I mean by scale? Well, in this
context, it's that a large oversized rug
helps define the boundaries of the
space. It makes the room feel
intentionally laid out, not like
furniture was scattered across the
floor. Even in large or open concept
spaces, an oversized rug can create the
visual sense of a unified area, which
makes the room feel rooted and
thoughtfully scaled. What I mean by
cohesion is that when a neutral rug
extends under multiple pieces of
furniture, like a sofa, chairs, and a
coffee table, it ties those pieces
together. Instead of each feeling like
it's floating or separate, the rug
creates a visual connection between
them. That unified foundation brings
balance and harmony to the layout, which
is especially important in minimalist or
structured spaces where every element
has to feel intentional.
Rug five is the cowhide or hide rug.
You'll find these used in rooms that
feel bold, rugged, or cinematic. These
add asymmetry and a dose of masculine
edge. They'll bring movement and
contrast. Great for serious or shadowy
rooms. They're an excellent finishing
touch in spaces with iron, aged wood, or
vintage leather. If you want, you can
layer them over something like a juke
rug, which forms an attractive
combination. So, when do you choose
cowhide versus a different animal hide?
Cowhide is thick, tough, and it's
wearresistant. It's ideal for those
hightraic areas. It's large in size
bold in pattern. It has that
unmistakably western, rustic, and
masculine edge. There's a strong texture
contrast it provides, but it's smooth
and slightly glossy, not plush-like. It
goes very well in rooms with leather
furniture, wood tones, and rugged
elements. Other popular hides are
sheepkin and caribou hides. These are
extremely plush and warm to the touch
more for comfort as opposed to drama.
They're often draped over furniture
benches or beds, not so much used
underfoot in large areas. They feel
cozy. They're more Scandinavian and
soft, not rugged or bold. You can also
consider goat or other exotic hides.
Their texture and look are more for
niche areas, often smaller with shorter
hair and less dramatic patterns. These
are chosen for specific color variations
or layering effects on chairs and
ottomans. Ultimately, choose cowhide
when you want a bold, durable rug that
adds edge, masculinity, and grounded
visual interest. Choose other hides when
you want softness, layering, or a cozy
accent, not a flooring foundation.
Remember that if you would like our team
to design your space for you, you can
have that help in the description below.
You now have five powerful rug styles
and how to use them to amplify your
space. If you like the video, hit the
thumbs up. If you feel like sticking
around a while, feel free to subscribe.
See you on the next one.
[Music]
[Music]

black leather so the pieces feel intentional they're bold and they're refined they stand out as signature elements and not just another seat in the living room the top grain leather Chesterfield sofa is a knockout piece in this room it's not part of a matching set because it shouldn't be match would have diluted its drama these Chester fields are really something to appreciate if you have the means to include them in your space elegant nail head trim wood framing with a sturdy base 100% genuine leather with rolled arms chef's kiss the mix of a distressed conac leather Chesterfield sofa and transcripts.title: We Turned a Work Van into a Speakeasy & Cigar Lounge

transcript.text: The other day, I asked myself if we
could turn a painters's van into a speak
easy. Well, we did. Think of this as a
way better version of van life. Have you
seen some of those van life photos? I
would rather wake up chained to a pole
in a Saw movie than inside one of those
coffins. Now, normally standing outside
of a van and asking people to get in is
frowned upon, but this should work out.
The exterior of this will still be
basic, but the interior will be a luxury
speak easy and cigar lounge. We have a
couple of issues with turning a vehicle
that isn't supposed to be a lounge into
a lounge. The first is going to be the
height. If you try to stand up inside of
this van, you're quickly going to find
yourself sitting back down with a
concussion. The second is the width. The
majority of the van is 4 and 1/2 ft
wide. Once you start putting stuff in
here, it can get real claustrophobic
real fast. We'll need to use some
techniques to make people feel like
they're on a trip to a nice dinner and
not a trip to prison. Let's walk through
what we created. This isn't your typical
van life setup. It isn't a limousine
knockoff, and it's not a lastminute
throw together. What we designed is a
speak easy on wheels, a hidden, refined
lounge inside of a painters van. Every
choice was made to feel like secret
luxury. One of the most striking details
is the ceiling. We installed a warm
amber mural of the sky during sunset. It
instantly warms the space and it sets
the tone for the evening. The purpose of
it was to subconsciously tell your
brain, "It's golden hour. It's time to
unwind with cocktails, conversation, and
good company." Most van ceilings are
just blank spaces, but here it draws the
eye upward and adds a layer of
personality that you'd never expect
inside of a work van. We place tufted
whiskey brown leather seating in an
L-shape that hugs the perimeter. It's a
direct nod to the classic gentleman's
lounges. It's rich, it's classic, and
it's comfortable. To break up the tone
and add a bit of contrast, we used red
velvet pillows, which also help anchor
the space visually. If you're looking at
this and thinking, you know what, I
would like a room like this, just not in
the back of a van. We can help you with
that. If you want a whiskey lounge, a
home office, a basement, or really any
other design, you can click the link in
the description below. The booth seating
was customized to fit the tight
footprint. It's only 21 in deep and it's
about a foot and a half high. It's
compact, but it is functional. The vibe
of the space is subtle, but it's
layered. We focused on adding warmth
without making it feel too heavy. The
floor is black hardwood, which blends
into the background while keeping the
space grounded. On top of that, we added
a cowhide rug that adds softness and a
slight Western Lodge edge. It breaks up
the darkness and brings balance to the
textures. The walls are painted black
magic by Sherwin Williams. This is a
bold black, but it has a bit of warm
undertone. The seating and the cabinetry
look almost black in low light, but if
you were to get up close, you would see
they're actually a warm charcoal called
weather vein, which is also made by
Sherwin Williams. It's a deep natural
tone, almost like an aged tree bark. The
bar cabinetry and display cases are 2
feet tall and they extend about a foot
and a half from the wall. They leave a 2
and 1/2 ft walkway through the middle
which is perfect because that's just
enough room to move around comfortably.
We designed them to feel like a small
luxury suite with glass fronts, marble
countertops, and soft down lighting.
There's also mirrored backs within the
cabinetry to visually open up the space.
The mini fridge holds 62 12 cans, which
is more than enough for a small group
unless you don't plan on waking up in
the morning. On the left side you have
your drinks. On the right side you have
your cigars. A 75count humidor holds the
core collection with a smaller executive
box humidor on top for the night's
picks. There's also a tabletop cutter
which has a quad guillotine because the
cut of your cigar is always important.
There's more though. We dialed in the
lighting. The back of a van is pitch
dark and with no clean lines, your eyes
don't know where to go. So, we ran LED
strip lighting along the floor and along
the ceiling edges. It doesn't just light
the space. It sculpts it. It mimics that
low, moody ambiance you find in an
underground lounge while still being
totally functional. You get shadows, you
get depth, and suddenly that space feels
much larger than it actually is. To
bring life into the room, we added
plants. We added a fruit bowl and also a
framed landscape painting. It softens
the edges and pulls the space away from
feeling like a project and more towards
feeling like an actual room. So, the
next time you see a work van on the
road, just remember there could be a
luxury lounge behind those doors. If you
like the video, hit the thumbs up. If
you feel like sticking around a while
feel free to subscribe. See you on the
next
[Music]
one. Seriously.

if a piece is large and it feels

Hollow and it's not going to last the
third thing is testing the stability
when you press down on a piece of

mix natural rugged materials that add

second is going to be genuine leather

beneath that you're going to find things

what holds up the best well Hardwoods as

density fiber board these go by the AC
hdf these are the strongest engineered
wood options the worst that you're going
to come across are probably particle
board and pressed wood they're weak

transcript.text: a lot of men live in homes that feel
more like temporary crash pads than
actual places to unwind and recharge
what's missing it's Comfort character
and intention here's the truth the way
that your home looks and feels directly
impacts your mindset a cold lifeless
space will drain you and your guests but
a thoughtfully designed space can lift
your mood your confidence and your
energy but don't worry you can create a
home that feels welcoming and stylish
without draining your wallet and the
past year we've helped hundreds of men
transform their rooms and we found out
what works and what does not work today
I'm sharing a few simple steps that will
help you turn your place into a
comfortable inviting space you and your
guests will enjoy step one is going to
be adding Greenery with highquality fake
plants using plants is one of the
simplest ways to breathe life into your
home they create color they have texture
and warmth they make any room feel more
welcoming but keeping the plants alive
can be difficult for those that have
busy schedules so what's the answer the
answer is high quality artificial plants
they need no upkeep and their options
look incredibly lifelike on today's
market if you have a big corner of your
room that feels empty try filling it
with a taller plant that has some volume
to it maybe you have a small area on a
bookcase or a tabletop that could use a
splash of color small plants would be
perfect perfect for this if men are
going to do something they like to know
why what's the benefit what's the payoff
how does this help the answer is that
plants are helping you reach a prime
mental state studies show that plants
being around your home reduce stress
they make you feel more relaxed and they
even boost happiness this happens
because humans naturally feel connected
to Nature it's a concept called
biophilia just seeing Greenery can
create a sense of calm and peace within
you green is gentle on the eyes and it
helps ease mental fatigue plants natural
shapes and patterns are simple for our
brains to process making them naturally
calming here are five artificial plants
that you can use to fill large spaces
and to create a natural inviting Vibe
the first is going to be a fiddle leaf
fig it adds a bold sculptural element
with large glossy leaves the second is
going to be a rubber tree it's perfect
for corners it's wide it has dark leaves
and it brings depth and richness to the
space the third is going to be the Swiss
cheese plant this gives a tropical touch
with its unique and split leaves the
fourth is going to be the snake plant
it's tall and it's sleek and it has
striking vertical leaves it's great for
modern or minimalist spaces and then the
last one I have for you today is an
olive tree and that adds a hint of
Mediterranean charm perfect for a
relaxed Airy type style now there are
four plants for the smaller spaces that
I want to share with you the first one
which I used often are succulents these
are perfect for desks shelves and coffee
tables they're really Compact and
they're flexible in terms of where they
can be used the second is going to be
Devil's Ivy this is great for
bookshelves and hanging uh Planters
especially for a cascading look from the
ceiling the third is going to be mini
fiddle leaf figs we did talk about their
older brother above these bring the same
charm as their larger version but they
have a scaled down um area that they
take up for for tighter spots the fourth
is going to be spider plants these are
perfect for window sills or small
hanging baskets step two is going to be
adding some personal touches personal
touches make your home feel warm and
unique by reflecting your interest it's
an easy way to turn what you love into
Decor so you're going to start with
framed photos or art work that could
resonate with you if you're not sure
where to begin try out these ideas
nature scenes these could be mountains
or beaches or forests you can try travel
photos with unique perspectives on city
views Street Scenes or nature you can
try animals especially ones that are
native to your area it's really cool to
see the animals outside that live in
your area inside your home in some way
you could try old buildings with um old
architecture like castles classic or
european architecture and then the last
one I have for you are photos of your
favorite vacation spots that will bring
up some great memories for you books and
collectibles can also be an awesome
Decor vinyl records vintage uh cameras
memorabilia or hobby things like um
hobby gear guitars or crossbows or would
be perfect examples a couple ways to
display them would be using wall mounts
floating shelves or display cases and
you can also use wall hooks or floor
stands especially for those guitars
these little details turn your house
into a space that feels more like you
step three is going to be creating a
signature scent smell plays a big role
in setting the mood for your home it can
trigger memories and make a space feel
more cozy and more familiar for example
the scent of vanilla or baked goods can
bring back memories of childhood or
family gatherings while fresh Citrus
gives a space a clean type of welcoming
feeling when there are too many strong
scents within a home it can feel
overwhelming a subtle Pleasant fragrance
that consistently travels throughout the
home helps create a more calm and
inviting atmosphere it can even become a
signature scent that both you and your
guests will remember to add fragrances
to your home you can use things like
essential oil diffusers you can use
candles Reed diffusers linen sprays or
even natural items like eucalyptus
bundles you can hang those in your
shower many men choose the route of
going with candles so here are some
masculine candle scents that you can try
in your own home Sandalwood uh Cedar
Wood Oak Moss tobacco and vanilla Amber
leather Fireside and clove and cinnamon
step four is to declutter and organize a
clutter-free home is more peaceful and
it's easier to live in I have six
techniques to help you get organized
without sacrificing the style that
you've built the first is going to be
using vertical space you can install
shelves to store books or decor and
remove small items from the floor the
second is going to be putting cabinets
in bedrooms for extra storage people
forget that this useful trick exists and
it's great especially for those that are
limited on closet space the third is
going to be using organizers that hang
over doors for Closet Storage always
hang those on the inside of the door so
that they're not visible from the
outside set up Peg boards in your office
for equipment or devices maybe extra
wires that you have hanging around the
second main step here is going to be
using hidden storage and that's going to
be choosing furniture with uh hidden
storage like beds that have drawers or
coffee tables that open up you can also
use decorative containers that blend in
with your decor and hide small items
these could be like um canisters
decorative canisters or chests or trunks
something that adds to the the space yet
has a functional purpose as well thirdly
embracing minimalism follow the one in
one out rule if you bring something new
into your home remove something old only
keep things that are useful and have
some sort of sentimental value to you
the fourth is going to be keeping
surfaces clear keeping counter tops
clear by designating spots for items
like kitchen tools Tech or grooming
products can help tremendously spend a
few minutes each day tidying up and
keeping those surfaces clutter-free it's
much easier to spend a little time each
day than to let it pile up and have to
spend hours on it at some point because
that time is coming step five is going
to be adding texture to your walls
adding texture to your walls can make
your home feel more cozy in several ways
the first is going to be the visual
warmth and depth that it adds flat
smooth walls they can feel a bit cold
and a little empty it's actually
happening to me right behind my new
setup here because I haven't hung the
art yet but when you add texture like
plaster or wood paneling or textured
wallpaper it makes the room feel warmer
and more inviting the light that hits
the textures creates shadows and that
adds depth and it gives the space more
emotion secondly it's going to reduce
the uh the noise that's in the room it
has a noise reduction purpose textured
walls can help absorb a sound making the
room quieter this is especially useful
if you live in a noisy area or you have
lots of foot traffic around you with
less noise the space becomes more
peaceful it becomes easier to focus
you're more productive touchable Comfort
different textures like rough stones and
soft Fabrics they engage your sense of
touch this makes the room feel more
interesting and pleasant because you can
feel you can feel those surfaces that
are around you now some ideas that you
can use on your walls shiplap or slats
tapestry uh or fabric panels you can use
3D wall art or sculptures you can use
stone or brick veneer textured wallpaper
like grass cloth or woven design these
are all small changes but together they
will make a big impact
if you would like our help in designing
your room you can have that help by
clicking the link in the description
below and if you want to see how we've
designed some other masculine rooms you
can click this playlist right here see
you on the next one
[Music]

transcript.text: most men design their bedrooms
completely wrong and it's ruining the
space where they should feel the most at
ease now why does this happen a lot of
men tend to focus more on function
rather than appearance and presentation
when you forget about the look and feel
of a room it's hard for it to not feel
random if your bedroom feels dull or
thrown together with no real style
you're not alone but there is good news
it's easy to fix your bedroom isn't just
a place to sleep it's where you start
and end your day when it's designed well
it helps you feel more relaxed confident
and in control of your surroundings in
the past year we've designed over 300
masculine rooms today I'm going to share
with you the biggest mistakes guys make
when designing their bedrooms and how to
fix those mistake number one is not
having a plan before you buy anything
ask yourself how do I want my room to
feel better yet how do you want it to
make you feel if you're life is
stressful you might want a calm
minimalist bedroom with lighter colors
and simple Furniture a space that helps
you unwind if you're at a stage where
things are going smoothly and you want
to bring in a bit more personality a
bold and Moody look could work for you
where you surround yourself with art
books memorabilia and other meaningful
objects to you when you have a clear
idea of how you want your room to feel
it's much easier to choose furniture and
decor that work together mistake number
two is not knowing the three Essentials
those are color lighting and texture
color too much of one color can make
your room feel flat my advice is to pick
three to five colors that you make your
room's color scheme break them down like
this the first color can be your main
color it will be about 50% of your room
the second color can be a support color
it complements the main color and this
might be uh 30 5% of your room the last
color is your accent color use this
color for things like pillows and art an
accent wall in the corner its job is to
add interest and only appear in roughly
15% of the room lighting your one
ceiling light is just not enough
lighting has a big effect on your mood
do you feel the same in a dimly lit
Steakhouse as you do in a bright dentist
office a steakhouse uses soft light to
create a relaxing setting your
comfortable you eat and you drink more
you take your time the dentist puts a
truck headlight 12 in from your face to
eliminate any and all Shadows it's
necessary but it makes you tense up a
bit you definitely don't want to stay
any longer than needed having two to
three different forms of light in your
room allows you to create different
moods additional light options could be
floor lamps bedside table lamps wall
sconces LED strips or dimmable balls
bulbs texture what's the secret to a
well-rounded space mixing authentic
materials see much of the furniture you
have today is Blended man-made material
like plastic aluminum polymers things
they make diapers out of use some
natural materials in your bedroom and I
promise you will feel the difference
look for real wood leather linen cotton
wool naturally occurring things mistake
number three is the wrong Furniture
choices most men either over complicate
their Furniture choices or they don't
think about them at all here are four
ways to get it right the first is to
pick a quality bed frame that provides
durability and style if you're going to
spend a bit more on something this is
the place styles that work for masculine
bedrooms include Sleek wood frames
lowprofile platforms or leather and
linen upholstered frames number two is
to choose the right bedside tables match
them to your room style for a more
modern look go with minimalist tables
for something classic pick wood or
vintage designs number three is finding
a statement piece this could be a large
art piece a sculpture a bold accent
chair or an eye-catching light fixture
something where people's eyes go towards
number four is using a properly sized
area rug large bedrooms like master
bedrooms usually use use an area rug
that's about 9 by 12 ft in size a medium
bedroom like a guest bedroom would use
an 8 by 10 foot sized area rug and
smaller bedrooms with maybe a bed that's
only a twin or a full-sized bed those
would usually use a 6X 9 ft area rug
mistake number four is going to be using

at all here's a simple guide to how you

600 in thread count you'll see it on the

now there's a lot of different
decorative pillows but two to three Euro

this could be wool cashmere or a
textured knit drape it over the edge or
throw it over the corner to add some
character to your bedding mistake number

knowing that the landlord is going to
make me switch it all back when I move

moving so do bite the bullet and
decorate your heart out decide that
you'll deal with removing it all later

what you'll find you're allowed to hang

obviously welcome to include any
furniture or small Decor that you're
bringing with you what landlords get
more hesitant about is painting
switching out light fixtures attaching
any type of built-ins which are larger
than a a small shelf meaning something
like a big built-in bookcase that has
hooks that go into the wall changing
flooring cabinet colors and countertops
are things that they have hesitancy over
modifying these types of things can
affect the rentability of the unit in
the future because now that unit is too
tailored to one person's taste that
lowers the demographic to which the
landlord can Market their property too
and that's a problem for them aside from
all of this these heavier modifications
are more invasive and they require a lot
more effort for you to reverse BT back
which is probably something you don't
want to deal with when you know that
you're going to move the only thing I
want to mention before I show you the

it has white paint on the walls there's
a Brownwood kitchen the cabinets match

door hand the kitchen faucet and the
Cabinetry PSE the other item which we
needed to incorporate into this design
is something that Zack already had which
was this Ikea golden brown sofa these
four base colors gray black white and

mother palette and everything else you
include in this room should share some
type of familial bond with them let's
take a look at we came up
with now this is something that you and
your friends can happily walk into what
a difference from from getting what we
started with to having a welcoming feel
you get to experience Comfort within
your apartment and have a sense of Joy
when you're returning to it from being
out and about the second step is to look
at choosing your rug rugs tend to be
afterthoughts when people decorate a
room they have everything set set up and
they think to themselves my God I need a
rug let me go see what I can find almost
always this results in the rug looking
like exactly what it is an afterthought
it leads to a desperate attempt to try
to include something that can cover the
bare floor if you don't have furniture
yet or you have very limited Furniture I
would encourage you to try to pick your
rug first why the area rug of a room has
one of the largest appearan impacts
think of a room as your body the
furniture as your
attributes when someone sees you what
are they noticing first you might say
well I've been working on these biceps
they're probably noticing those those
are your accent chairs or maybe you're
thinking my mother always told me I have
a a great smile they'll probably looking
at that that is the artwork on your
walls I have these great calves look at
these perfect diamonds those are plants
in the corner of your room the first
thing they notice is your skin your skin
is the largest and most apparent thing
on your body why do you think women
spend so much time moisturizing they
take 15minute sessions just to put
lotion on their skin they know that
their skin is very important and they're
very aware of how other people notice it
people forget that area rugs are very
likely the largest Decor piece you will
have in your room put some thought into
it beforehand and the rest of the space
will come together in a more easy
fashion how do we choose the right rug
let me share with you a fairly safe
approach that almost always works in
apartments look at your wall color now
look at your flooring and then your
kitchen cabinets take those colors
combine them you have your rug or at
least a selection of rugs for us we
chose an ivory rug which has hint of
gray and brown the ivory color itself is
a mixture of white with warm undertones
I personally prefer to have some
contrast between the rug and the floor
so I tend to choose a rug whose dominant
color leans more in a opposite tone of
the floor's dominant tone step three
would be choosing your seating this was
somewhat done for us because Zach
already had this great leather sofa what
makes it great is that if you're going
to use a pop of color in your room your
sofa or accent chairs are a great place
to do it do you want blue do you want
green do you want orange go for it we
didn't use a tremendous amount of color
in the rest of the room because we knew
that this large piece of furniture was
going to fulfill that need if you wanted
to go really bold like a very deep uh
vibrant orange on the couch it would be
a handsome look orange would still be a
family member of the mother pallet which
we spoke of earlier and that would be
fine step four is choosing our coffee
table the coffee table is an important
asset to a living room but it becomes
critical when it's a small living room
it plays a crucial role because the eyes
have fewer directions to which they can
wander in a tight area if people's eyes
are already going to this coffee table
let's give them some something to look
at a heavy solid black Grain coffee
table that table is the anchor that is
bringing the entire scene of the room to
a center it is the beacon that is
letting visitors know this room was
completed with purpose why black to tie
to the accent Hues of the light fixtures
and the hardware to the floor why black
grain to complement the wood textures of
the kitchen cabinets and why a rectangle
because it mimics the shape of the room
and it visually fits it like a puzzle
piece step five is going to be choosing
the right entertainment console size
that's the table where typically is
located under your TV when I say
choosing the right size I'm not
referring to the width or the span of
the furniture piece across the wall but
the depth to which it protrudes away
from the wall the depth can be the
killer of a well-laid out out room the
size of the sofa and the coffee table
you've chose along with the width of
your living room are going to be the
deciding factors in choosing your
entertainment console each month I'm
going to give away a free room design
I'm going to select this winner from the
group of people who follow the
newsletter so how do you follow the
newsletter there's going to be a link
down in the description of this video
that will allow you to subscribe to it
after that you're automatically entered
every month for a CH to win a free room
design do you know how wide the average
interior door of a home is it's 36 in
that's because for most people 3 ft is a
comfortable width to walk through you
can use the same principle when creating
walking paths in your home measure 36 in
from your coffee table toward where the
TV console is going to be then measure
from that point to the wall that will
let you know the depth measurement that
you shouldn't exceed when choosing a
console if your living room is
exceedingly narrow and you can't make it
work my suggestion is to mount your TV
on the wall as opposed to having it
placed at top a table and just forego
the table completely if you absolutely
need something under your TV using a
simple floating shelf is absolutely an
option step six is a wonderful technique
but it can only be used if it presents
itself luckily it often does present
itself in apartments and condo layouts
take a look around the the room and see
if there is anything that you can
enhance that could trick a person into
thinking that the home was created that
way do you see how it was done in this
particular room that back corner column
would be viewed by a lot of people as a
negative to the room because of its
encroaching nature but can you find a
way to make it an asset you can by
portraying it as an exposed concrete
structure of the building covering this
column in a
concrete artificial concrete peel and
stick wallpaper allowed us to add a bit
of industrial charm to the room and kept
us away from using that paint that the
landlord probably wouldn't like or we
don't want to go through reverting peel
and stick wallpaper has the same
application process as a giant sticker
it's not nearly as involved as the
traditional water activated w paper it's
very easy to remove and it's inexpensive
to buy the last step I might have a
bonus tip for you after this but the
last step I'm going to mention today is
more of a point of advice in regards to
the framed artwork that you may put on
your
walls sometimes when you hang art on
your wall you step back and you look at
it and it feels it just it feels too big
it's too heavy or it's disproportionate
to the room so the most intuitive
adjustment that someone would take would
be to find smaller artwork and put that
up but after doing that you step back
again and you look at it and you say
well now this is too small what do I do
here the issue you're running into is
that you're attempting to solve a
density issue with a sizing resolve you
can navigate around this by choosing a
large frame with a few inches of white
spacing the spacing is called matting
when you're looking for this online or
in a store what you're looking for are
picture frames with mat this setup will
allow you to choose a larger frame
proportion while simultaneously removing
some of the density from the body of the
art ideally it should result in a more
overall pleasing aesthetic appearance
now here's the bonus tip and the
overarching theme when choos using Color
Hues or textures and shapes within a
room some of the best comedians in the
world can orchestrate their jokes to
quickly mention something that is
seemingly insignificant could be a
phrase at the beginning of their story
which we don't pay much attention to and
then all of a sudden 15 minutes later
they come full circle and they hit us
with a punchline that references the
beginning of the story everyone is sent
into hysterical laughter it's not just
the humor that has everyone laughing but
it's the appreciation of the ability to
connect two topics or or two parts of a
story that appeared to not be related at
all you are taking a similar approach
when orchestrating the design of your
room the tones and the textures within
your room should communicate with each
other from different areas you have
white on your walls how can you bring
some white to the floor you have texture
on your floor how can you bring some of
that texture to your ceiling if the view
from outside of your window is dense
Green Forest how do we bring some of

these characteristics as satellites
communicating to each other within the
space that is your room you don't want
your room to look like a Ronald McDonald
outfit but it's nice to see a color make

present itself in apartments and condo layouts take a look around the the room and see if there is anything that you can enhance that could trick a person into thinking that the home was created that way do you see how it was done in this particular room that back corner column would be viewed by a lot of people as a negative to the room because of its encroaching nature but can you find a way to make it an asset you can by portraying it as an exposed concrete structure of the building covering this column in a concrete artificial concrete peel and stick wallpaper allowed us to add a bit of industrial charm to the room and kept us away from using that paint that the landlord probably wouldn't like or we don't want to go through reverting peel and stick wallpaper has the same application process as a giant sticker it's not nearly as involved as the traditional water activated w paper it's very easy to remove and it's inexpensive to buy the last step I might have a bonus tip for you after this but the last step I'm going to mention today is more of a point of advice in regards to the framed artwork that you may put on your walls sometimes when you hang art on your wall you step back and you look at it and it feels it just it feels too big it's too heavy or it's disproportionate to the room so the most intuitive adjustment that someone would take would be to find smaller artwork and put that up but after doing that you step back again and you look at it and you say well now this is too small what do I do here the issue you're running into is that you're attempting to solve a density issue with a sizing resolve you can navigate around this by choosing a large frame with a few inches of white spacing the spacing is called matting when you're looking for this online or in a store what you're looking for are picture frames with mat this setup will allow you to choose a larger frame proportion while simultaneously removing some of the density from the body of the art ideally it should result in a more overall pleasing aesthetic appearance now here's the bonus tip and the overarching theme when choos using Color Hues or textures and shapes within a room some of the best comedians in the world can orchestrate their jokes to quickly mention something that is seemingly insignificant could be a phrase at the beginning of their story which we don't pay much attention to and then all of a sudden 15 minutes later they come full circle and they hit us with a punchline that references the beginning of the story everyone is sent into hysterical laughter it's not just the humor that has everyone laughing but it's the appreciation of the ability to connect two topics or or two parts of a story that appeared to not be related at all you are taking a similar approach when orchestrating the design of your room the tones and the textures within your room should communicate with each other from different areas you have white on your walls how can you bring some white to the floor you have texture on your floor how can you bring some of that texture to your ceiling if the view from outside of your window is dense Green Forest how do we bring some of that Greenery inside the home consider these characteristics as satellites communicating to each other within the space that is your room you don't want your room to look like a Ronald McDonald outfit but it's nice to see a color make a second appearance you have now seen some of the steps that we took in creating a renter friendly apartment that you can use in your own home if you like the video hit the thumbs up if you feel like sticking around a while feel free to subscribe see you on the next one

------
Designing a basement can be challenging due to its open, undefined space, making it hard to visualize a cohesive layout. Unlike other rooms with predefined purposes, basements require strategic planning to avoid awkward gaps or unnecessary furniture. 

Today we have tips to divide and transform your basement into a functional, stylish area that maximizes its potential. Learn how to reimagine this expansive space and create a design that inspires.

------

statement room for the entire house
modern industrial was going to be the

nothing industrial about it so we had
some work to do a few requests that John

throwing them out and replacing them

and a quick side note here on their own
there's nothing wrong with gray floors
there are incredible interior Styles out

only when everything else in the room is
also grayscale that's when it be comes
really
tiresome another thing was to have
somewhere for guests to sit when either
not playing pool or simply watching the

great beverage would be nice displaying
some of Jon's interest were also

for vintage trucks motorcycles exotic

of the land let's show what we did how
we went about doing it and how you can
also do it barely recognizable just the
way we like it and a super cool space
that will keep people coming back just
to see it again I do want to mention
something which I've never mentioned in
a video before and once I do you'll
likely begin to view rooms in a
different way that will be really
beneficial to you forever room layouts
that are pleasing to the eye are
visually attractive because of the
patterns being created by imaginary
lines when you design all of the
time this becomes second nature to you
and you no longer think about it but as
someone who doesn't do this as often
remembering this principle is helpful if

geometric shapes as if it were a game of

anyone else who is unfamiliar with this
concept it creates Harmony and balance
among the pieces in the room it
eliminates overcrowding it ensures that

purpose let's talk about the layering

industrial but before we start thinking

achieve
it exposed trusses are also an excellent

we've spoke about that in previous

this they're much lighter in weight and
can be mounted with relative ease not a
single one of these has structural

authentically bracing the structure of
the house the far wall is now looking a

material IAL to the other walls for a
recreation room like this there's two

the entire floor line of the wall you
may be thinking well that's cool but why

dealing with large windows that stretch

in front of it you interrupt the window
line and it throws off the alignment
tabletops and beds are huge culprits of
doing this we wanted to nav Navigate
around this mistake that's often made
the fireplace facade is a glossy ceramic

of marble and of course they have it in
Gray neither the sheen of this nor the

would find in an industrial setting we
replaced this with a matte porcelain

texture and the natural tone complement
the style we were creating or going for
much better the Outer Perimeter is now

on top of the first layer yes the outer
walls are much more interesting than the

mentioned three pillars to a great
design color texture and dimension this

of your favorite mountable decor and art
and start placing it on the walls if you
have utility needs for the room like we

display the pool sticks this is the time
to consider that be mindful though of
the space that you have available to
yourself you don't want to go overboard
with mounting things on the wall because
then your first layer of the design is
completely lost side note if you want a
free room design from us there's a link
in the description below to have that
chance step three furniture and main
pieces imagine the this room only having
what we've discussed thus far be
complete The Brick is on the walls the

bench is installed the artwork is
mounted can you see how much easier it
is now to choose furniture and large
pieces it's very hard to go wrong people
make it harder on themselves when they
buy furniture without Direction and then
try to mold the room to fit the
furniture look at what we would have so
far and then ask yourself could I stick
a brown leather chair in here absolutely
it goes very well with the color palette
could a Blackwood tabletop go in here of
course the color black and the material
wood are both used here should I stick
an orange suede chair with gold legs in
here no it doesn't make sense step four
is not required but it can be fun the
statement piece there are plenty of
interesting things happening within this
room but the
undeniable star is that motorcycle bar
cart statement pieces can be luxury
items that supersede the other items in

can be unique artworks that are more
rarely found they can be a niche or a
quirky item that speaks to your personal
interests and personality whatever it
may be even if you think it doesn't
exist I encourage you to do a Google
search for it because the internet is a
large place we still still wanted to
incorporate a motorcycle in this design
and we still needed a bar display and
wouldn't you know someone out there was

seen the creation of a room in a layered
process if you like this video hit the

[Music]
