transcripts.title: I Made an Executive Masculine Home Office

transcript.text: How we walk the line between work and
home is an interesting thing, especially
if you have found success within your
designated profession or your
entrepreneurial venture. As you grow
within your chosen industry, as you move
up the ladder financially, it's very
often that you find yourself growing
personally. Who you have to become in
order to gain traction within your
professional life ends up influencing
who you are privately. We begin to view
ourselves through a different lens. We
finally acknowledge that we have earned
qualities and traits that can only be
born through hardship and perseverance.
Now, this isn't to be confused with
being unpleasantly arrogant. This is
simply recognizing that if you took a
step back and looked at yourself as if
you were another person, you know that
you could confidently say, "I'm
impressed with them." Though the
predominant feeling amongst people about
who they are at work is to get there
get done, and get out as fast as
possible, those of us who feel passion
and drive behind our work know that the
professional characteristics we carry
outside of the home inevitably follow us
back to our homes because we have
internalized those qualities. My name is
Charrey and today I'm showing you how we
created an executive home office that
demands respect yet embodies warmth at
the same time. If you're a returning
subscriber, hit the thumbs up. If you're
new here, hopefully by the end of this
video, you'll be a subscriber. Remember
that if you would like my help in
designing your room, you can have that
help by clicking the link in the
description below. Sood had filled out a
contact form with us stating that he was
purchasing a new home. It was in the
process of being built and therefore he
didn't have photos. He did have a floor
plan, however. So, it was our job to
make this room come to life before it
physically existed. His goal was to
create a home office that was masculine
and industrial. However, this was to be
a home version of an executive's office
which meant it needed to maintain a
refined look. The office was to provide
an easy transition when coming home for
the person who spends their time within
the executive level of their corporate
space. It would be warm, welcoming, and
personalized, yet still have the feeling
of holding a certain caliber of status.
Our approach to this was to lean more
into the dark and polished theme while
sprinkling in industrial accents. Saw
did have some requests for us to
incorporate within the design. He wanted
a sturdy, sizable executive desk, an
ergonomic office chair, a small sofa, a
bookshelf display, the addition of
texture to the walls, shades of gray
black, brown, or navy, and a light
fixture which could serve as a statement
piece. So, here is what we came up with.
I think we nailed what we were aiming
for on this one. There's always an
emotional response that one has when
entering a new room. And if class and a
respectable atmosphere were the goals
this did just that. We of course have
the overarching theme of moodiness with
the darker desaturated tones. And this
is balanced through the use of a lighter
wood flooring paired with a light woven
rug. The flooring you're seeing here is
by Bruce Flooring and it is part of
their forest rain collection. It's a
white oak with a stain that they call
tranquil warmth. Something that can make
a huge difference in a room is the width
of the individual planks on the floor.
These are 7in wide planks. They're about
three times the size of your traditional
wood flooring planks. If you have a
large room with taller ceilings, wider
planks will assist in continuing that
stately appearance. Two things happening
on the art wall to direct your attention
to. The first being the way scotting.
When adding trim to walls, it's very
common for people to create a small
repetition of boxes, filling the wall
entirely. I'm assuming that their
thought process is that if I'm going to
add molding and trim, I'm going to do a
lot so that this wall is definitely not
boring. What I would encourage you to do
is to treat every wall differently. Is
it a large wall? Is it a small wall? Is
it tall? Is it short? Is it wide? Is it
narrow? What's it being used for? Create
a trim that aesthetically matches what
the wall is already telling you it
wants. We knew that artwork was going to
go on this wall. The wall is huge, so
why not mimic the look of a large
picture frame? It's simple yet
effective. The second thing on this art
wall, the photo frames, by merely
adjusting them to a slightly different
alignment than what you would typically
see, it creates the illusion of this
swirling effect. It's a spiraling
pattern. It's something different. It's
something interesting. There's something
that I want to mention about the floor
to ceiling bookshelf. These, of course
show up in a lot of home office and
library designs, especially for those
that are attempting to create a
traditional or an academia look. They're
tall in stature. They're captivating
even more so when they're decorated
well. But if you're looking to add a bit
more modernity to them, a way to add
more visual depth, basic strip lighting
pressed to the top corner can highlight
your prized possessions, your unique
pieces, your memorabilia, and create
moody shadows that otherwise would not
be there. It's an easy addition and it's
something to consider. If you're
noticing the artwork above the desk, it
is made by an Italian artist named Jeppe
Beernney. He focuses on contemporary art
that has a lot of texturized patterns.
You'll find that much of his work
contains um earthy color palettes. It
was the perfect addition for a room that
was using browns, blacks, golds, and
needed some texture. Speaking of the
golds, the chandelier hangs boldly and
at center stage. It certainly serves its
purpose as being a statement piece. When
you walk into the room or sit at the
couch, this brushed gold finish acts as
a nucleus to the rest of the design.
It's as if it has a gravitational pole.
It's highlighting the gold frame around
Jeppe's art piece, the amber strip
lighting that we placed in the
bookshelves and the legs of the coffee
table. The two plants are placed at
opposite corners of the room. I've
mentioned this in previous designs, but
it's an excellent way to create some
additional balance in a space. Given the
rest of the room has a desaturated theme
to it, it made sense to choose darker
leafd plants. You have now seen the
creation of an executive's home office
that blends his professional life with
his home life. If you like the video
hit the thumbs up. If you feel like
sticking around a while, feel free to
subscribe. See you on the next one.

Entrepreneurs, founders, executives and independent contractors walk a fine-line between their professional and work lives, inevitably having the two blend and intertwine, resulting in who they are as a whole.  

They dress nicely, they have a professional appearance, they convey clear messages, they're talented in their work.... But what about their office space?  Is it up to par in representing who they are as individuals?

Today we take an executive's home office and shape it into a dark, moody, professional space that showcases who they are in the outside world, at home.

with your shoes or touching anything will give you anxiety we didn't want that the goal in this design was to create a sense of charm and admiration for a highclass space that would be comparable to the social rooms you would find within noteworthy golf clubhouses we did have some parameters a small list to work within that Rachel had mentioned to me she had an affection for the original Spanish tiling on the floor so our aim was to leave that alone and find a look which would complimented her and her husband had two sofas from their old house that they wanted to use one of them was a velvet green the other was a sort of tan camel type color one of their regular hosting events is poker night so we needed a space where that could be accomplished they loved the idea of bookshelves but they weren't sure if those current bookshelves in the room or the place of them was ideal Rachel used to be in the service and hospitality industry and knows her way around making a great cocktail in order to best serve their guests their friends their family they wanted direct accessibility to beverages glasses and the mixers used to create those drinks and finally their boys play piano and have been taking lessons so they were eager to have a place in the home where that piano could go here is what we came up with this room really came together given the color parameters we had between the two sofas and keeping the original flooring it actually worked out quite well because we were able to mimic the color combinations of what you would find on the green for those of you unfamiliar with the term that's part of the golf course you're out on The Fairway you're playing golf what are the colors that you're seeing when you look up varying colors of green Browns and reds from the wooded areas in the rough beiges and tans from the sand with in the bunkers and whites the golf ball itself Flags carts clouds in the sky we were able to bring all of those together making for an easygoing transition from course to home and from home to course considering that you can see the course from this room's window it really creates a sense of joy for someone who loves golf the paint color we used in the room is called fox hall green by Sherwin Williams this color is complex with its mixtures of slate and yellow undertones but it is so beautifully sophisticated the shade of the color works very well in rooms that have a bit of natural light from Windows or doors it does an excellent job of creating that Moody vibe that I know so many of you enjoy when standing in the living room and looking towards the window and door there's quite a bit to break down here so let's try to quickly disassemble the design in its totality and see see why it works the two sofas I mentioned these were going to go into the room regardless and we needed to design around them the Velvet green sofa makes it quite obvious as to what how and why we arrived at our paint color as for the other sofa the tan one this particular shade was not something I was looking to use more than once in the room but I had no problem in using other colors which could be extracted from that tan shade remember that nearly every color is simply the sum of a bunch of other colors mixed together if you're able to pull the colors out as if they were ingredients in a recipe you're likely to find something that you can pair nicely in the room this leads us to the beige colored drapes it's part of that tan family and it serves the purpose of achieving the sand tones we wanted from the golf course now here's something you might have to pay a little bit more close attention to in order to pick up on if you were to take the sofa and you put it in a blender with the drapes the Hue that you would come out with would be something very similar to that of the wood beams that we put on the ceiling that stain on that wood is called warm caramel and that is how we tied the tan from the low point to the high point you might be asking why would you even bother putting the wood beams on the ceiling at all golf is quite an old sport it stems from the 15th century if you were to picture Interiors from that time frame you could expect to see a lot of peaked ceilings and a lot of exposed truss trusses even the ceilings that were not peaked in those times it would be likely that you would see some type of raw framework and decorative ceiling pattern our inclusion of the be the wood beams it pays homage to the age of the sport and the times in which it originated the piano found its home in front of the large window it does have that traditional gloss black coat to it black was not something we were initially trying to put in this design but we couldn't have the piano sitting out like a sore thumb and nothing to help blend it so we found it some friends nothing overbearing um small items that would assist the black in merging with the rest of the design a skinny floor lamp the light coffee table and a compact side table that was it looking at the fireplace side of the room is relatively straightforward on the wall you have a medley of three highdefinition photographs of Fairways we organized the photo frame sizing in such a way that seemed the most visually appealing oftentimes Gallery walls are something that you have to play around with sometimes you want a collection of photos to have a clear a clear edging a clear perimeter which they're all working within sometimes you allow for a little bit of play outside of those lines my best advice is to go with your gut then take 10 steps back look at it again and find out whether your gut was lying to you I wanted the fireplace here to be a point of interest but I didn't want the entire section of that wall to be the focal point as soon as you walk into the room dealing with this was a simple approach of making the brick Fade Into the background and pulling the fireplace into the foreground I did like the brick but I liked it for its texture not for its color so we continued the fox hall green right over it the fireplace itself had been treated like a second class citizen we gave it a fresh Ivory mantle surround to embrace it and provide that distinction it deserves the largest wall in the room did become the elongated bookshelf display the center of it has that glass paneling that you can see and that became the beverage and bar area if you're someone who has been wanting to include a bar or display in your room but you've struggled to find the space to do so try to reframe your mind from thinking of how to add more pieces into the room and instead focus on how you can repurpose something that you already have or finding a way that an existing piece can become multi-purpose we had no way to integrate a full-sized bar without crowding the room or the whole design becoming kind of tacky using a portion of the bookshelves to accommodate this feature seemed like a more graceful option with a smart look you have now seen the transformation of a living room with no personality reborn with a connection to its environment and the people that live within it if you like the video hit the thumbs up if you feel like sticking around a while feel free to subscribe

------
Establishing a true connection between those who live in a room and the room itself can make all the difference.  You will see children, with no restraints, decorate their rooms with tons of items and memorabilia from things they love.  Posters everywhere, toys, sports balls, figurines, dolls, etc. 
 
They do this because it makes the room feel like their own; There is an underlying connection of the hobbies and interests they have with the room.  For us as adults, we can use the same premise in designing a living room that creates a deep connection by including subtle hints of the loves our lives.
